docs.title: Metriq-Gym
docs.text: Metriq-Gym is an open-source framework for running standardized quantum benchmarks across different quantum hardware providers. It provides a unified CLI and Python interface to dispatch, monitor, and analyze benchmark jobs on simulators and real quantum devices.

docs.title: What is Metriq?
docs.text: Metriq-Gym is part of the Metriq ecosystem, a community-driven platform for tracking quantum computing progress. Results collected with Metriq-Gym can be uploaded to the Metriq platform to contribute to the global benchmarking database.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Multi-provider support: Run benchmarks on IBM Quantum, IonQ, AWS Braket, Azure Quantum, Quantinuum, OriginQ, and local simulators
  • Standardized benchmarks: 12+ benchmark implementations including Quantum Volume, CLOPS, Mirror Circuits, and more
  • Simple CLI: Dispatch jobs with a single command, poll for results, and upload to the community
  • Extensible: Add custom benchmarks and providers with a clean plugin architecture

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Install Metriq-Gym from PyPI:

pip install metriq-gym

docs.title: Quick Example
docs.text:
Run a benchmark on the local Aer simulator:

# Download an example configuration
curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/unitaryfoundation/metriq-gym/main/metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json

# Dispatch the benchmark
mgym job dispatch wit.example.json -p local -d aer_simulator

# Poll for results
mgym job poll latest

docs.title: BSEQ (Binary Sequence)
docs.text: The BSEQ benchmark measures device connectivity by identifying the largest connected subgraph of functioning qubits.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: BSEQ characterizes real device connectivity by testing two-qubit gates across the device topology. It identifies which qubit pairs can successfully execute entangling operations, revealing the effective connectivity of the device.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "BSEQ" shots integer No 1000 Measurement repetitions max_colors integer No all Maximum graph coloring iterations

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "BSEQ",
  "shots": 1000
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/bseq.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_sherbrooke

# Poll results
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Results
docs.text: Metric Description largest_connected_size Number of qubits in the largest working subgraph fraction_connected Ratio of connected qubits to total qubits

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
BSEQResult(largest_connected_size=100, fraction_connected=0.7874)

This indicates that 100 qubits form the largest connected component, representing 78.74% of the device.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Graph Coloring: The device topology is colored to identify parallel executable edges
  2. Bell State Preparation: For each edge, a Bell state is prepared
  3. Measurement: Correlation measurements determine if the edge is functional
  4. Connected Components: Functional edges are analyzed to find the largest connected subgraph

docs.title: Device Requirements
docs.text:
• Requires device topology information
  • Works best on devices with fixed connectivity (superconducting, neutral atom)
  • Fully-connected devices (trapped ion) will show 100% connectivity

docs.title: Interpretation
docs.text: Result Interpretation fraction_connected > 0.9 Excellent device health fraction_connected 0.7-0.9 Good, some defective qubits/couplers fraction_connected < 0.7 Significant connectivity issues

docs.title: References
docs.text: • Qiskit Device Benchmarking

docs.title: CLOPS (Circuit Layer Operations Per Second)
docs.text: CLOPS measures the throughput of a quantum system - how many circuit layer operations can be executed per second.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: CLOPS is IBM's standard benchmark for measuring quantum computer throughput. It accounts for: - Circuit compilation time - Job submission latency - Queue wait time - Execution time - Result retrieval

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "CLOPS" width integer No 1000 Circuit width (number of qubits) num_layers integer No 1000 Number of layers per circuit num_circuits integer No 100 Number of circuits to run shots integer No 1000 Shots per circuit

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "CLOPS",
  "width": 100,
  "num_layers": 100,
  "num_circuits": 100,
  "shots": 100
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/clops.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_sherbrooke

# Poll results
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Results
docs.text: Metric Description clops_score Circuit Layer Operations Per Second total_time Total execution time in seconds circuits_per_second Raw circuit throughput

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text: CLOPSResult(clops_score=25000, total_time=4.0)

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Circuit Generation: Creates num_circuits circuits with num_layers layers each
  2. Parameterization: Uses parameterized circuits updated between executions
  3. Timing: Measures total wall-clock time from first submission to last result
  4. Calculation: CLOPS = (circuits × layers × shots) / time

docs.title: CLOPS Formula
docs.text:
CLOPS = M × K × S × D / elapsed_time

Where: - M = number of circuit templates - K = number of parameter updates - S = number of shots - D = number of QV layers

docs.title: Device Requirements
docs.text:
• Works on any device
  • Meaningful comparison requires similar circuit structure
  • Best for comparing system-level performance

docs.title: Interpretation
docs.text:
CLOPS Interpretation > 100,000 Very high throughput (latest IBM systems) 10,000 - 100,000 High throughput 1,000 - 10,000 Moderate throughput < 1,000 Lower throughput (cloud overhead, simulator)

Note

CLOPS is heavily influenced by classical infrastructure, not just quantum hardware quality.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• IBM Quantum: What is CLOPS?
  • arXiv:2110.14108 - Volumetric Benchmarking Framework

docs.title: EPLG (Error Per Layered Gate)
docs.text: EPLG measures the error rate per layer of two-qubit gates using randomized benchmarking techniques.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Error Per Layered Gate (EPLG) characterizes the layer fidelity of a quantum device by running randomized benchmarking on linear qubit chains. It provides a scalable measure of how errors accumulate with circuit depth.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "EPLG" num_qubits_in_chain integer Yes - Number of qubits in the chain (min: 4) lengths array[int] No [2, 4, 8, 16] Circuit depths for benchmarking num_samples integer No 3 Random circuits per depth shots integer No 100 Shots per circuit seed integer No 12345 Random seed for reproducibility two_qubit_gate string No "cz" Two-qubit gate type (cz, cx, ecr) one_qubit_basis_gates array[str] No ["rz", "rx", "x"] Single-qubit basis gates decompose_clifford_ops boolean No false Decompose Clifford operations

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "EPLG",
  "num_qubits_in_chain": 10,
  "lengths": [2, 4, 8, 16],
  "num_samples": 3,
  "shots": 100,
  "two_qubit_gate": "cz"
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/eplg.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_sherbrooke

# Poll results
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Results
docs.text: Metric Description eplg Error Per Layered Gate value layer_fidelity Fidelity of a single layer fit_quality Goodness of exponential fit

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
EPLGResult(eplg=0.015, layer_fidelity=0.985)

This indicates a 1.5% error per layer, with 98.5% layer fidelity.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Chain Selection: A linear chain of qubits is selected on the device
  2. Layer Construction: Each layer applies random Clifford gates followed by two-qubit gates
  3. Inversion: An inverse layer is appended to return to the initial state
  4. Depth Sweep: Circuits are run at multiple depths
  5. Fitting: Survival probability is fit to an exponential decay

docs.title: Gate Selection
docs.text:
Choose gates native to your device:

Device Type Recommended two_qubit_gate IBM Eagle/Heron ecr or cz Google cz Rigetti cz IonQ/Quantinuum cx

docs.title: Interpretation
docs.text: EPLG Layer Fidelity Interpretation < 0.01 > 99% Excellent gate quality 0.01 - 0.03 97-99% Good for most applications 0.03 - 0.10 90-97% Error correction recommended > 0.10 < 90% High error rate

docs.title: Provider Notes
docs.text:
For some providers that don't support Qiskit Clifford primitives, enable decomposition:

{
  "decompose_clifford_ops": true
}

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• Layer Fidelity Benchmarking
  • Qiskit Experiments: Layer Fidelity

docs.title: LR-QAOA (Linear Ramp QAOA)
docs.text: The LR-QAOA benchmark evaluates a device's ability to solve combinatorial optimization problems using the Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm with linear parameter schedules.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Linear Ramp QAOA (LR-QAOA) applies QAOA to weighted MaxCut problems with linearly increasing parameters. This removes the need for classical optimization, making it a fair hardware benchmark that tests quantum operation quality rather than hybrid optimizer performance.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "Linear Ramp QAOA" graph_type string Yes - Graph topology: "1D", "NL", or "FC" num_qubits integer Yes - Number of qubits (min: 2) qaoa_layers array[int] No [3,5,7,10,15,20] QAOA circuit depths delta_beta float No 0.3 Beta parameter slope (0-2) delta_gamma float No 0.3 Gamma parameter slope (0-2) shots integer No 1000 Shots per circuit trials integer No 3 Circuits per configuration num_random_trials integer No 25 Random baseline circuits confidence_level float No 0.995 Statistical confidence seed integer No 123 Random seed

docs.title: Example Configurations
docs.text:
1D Chain Graph: 

{
  "benchmark_name": "Linear Ramp QAOA",
  "graph_type": "1D",
  "num_qubits": 10,
  "qaoa_layers": [3, 5, 7],
  "shots": 1000
}

Native Layout (Device Topology): 

{
  "benchmark_name": "Linear Ramp QAOA",
  "graph_type": "NL",
  "num_qubits": 20,
  "qaoa_layers": [3, 5, 10],
  "shots": 1000
}

Fully Connected: 

{
  "benchmark_name": "Linear Ramp QAOA",
  "graph_type": "FC",
  "num_qubits": 6,
  "qaoa_layers": [3, 5],
  "shots": 1000
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/lr_qaoa_1d_chain.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_sherbrooke

# Poll results
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Results
docs.text: Metric Description approximation_ratio Solution quality vs optimal success_probability Probability of finding good solutions layers_passed Maximum layers where QAOA outperforms random

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text: LRQAOAResult(approximation_ratio=0.85, layers_passed=7)

docs.title: 1D Chain ("1D")
docs.text:
• Linear chain of qubits
  • Each qubit connected to neighbors
  • Easiest to implement on most devices

docs.title: Native Layout ("NL")
docs.text:
• Uses device's actual connectivity
  • Most realistic benchmark
  • Requires device topology information

docs.title: Fully Connected ("FC")
docs.text:
• Every qubit connected to every other
  • Requires SWAP routing on real devices
  • Tests both gates and routing

docs.title: Linear Ramp Parameters
docs.text:
Parameters increase linearly with layer index p:

beta_p = delta_beta * (p + 0.5)
gamma_p = delta_gamma * (p + 0.5)

docs.title: Success Criteria
docs.text: LR-QAOA "passes" at layer p if: - The approximation ratio exceeds random guessing - With statistical confidence ≥ confidence_level

docs.title: Interpretation
docs.text: Approximation Ratio Interpretation > 0.9 Near-optimal solutions 0.8 - 0.9 Good solution quality 0.7 - 0.8 Acceptable for some applications < 0.7 Poor - noise dominates Layers Passed Interpretation > 15 Excellent coherence 10 - 15 Good coherence 5 - 10 Moderate coherence < 5 Short coherence times

docs.title: Device Requirements
docs.text:
• "NL" and "1D" work best on fixed-topology devices
  • "FC" requires SWAP networks (increased depth)
  • Use --device flag for topology-dependent configurations

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• arXiv:1411.4028 - A Quantum Approximate Optimization Algorithm
  • arXiv:2004.01372 - Fixed-angle QAOA

docs.title: Mirror Circuits
docs.text: Mirror Circuits benchmark measures circuit fidelity using self-inverting random Clifford circuits.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Mirror circuits are constructed to return to the initial state by mirroring the circuit: if the first half applies operations U, the second half applies U†. This allows measurement of total circuit fidelity without needing a reference simulation.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "Mirror Circuits" width integer No all qubits Number of qubits num_layers integer No 3 Number of Clifford layers (1-500) two_qubit_gate_prob float No 0.5 Probability of two-qubit gates (0-1) two_qubit_gate_name string No "CNOT" Gate type (CNOT or CZ) shots integer No 1000 Measurement shots num_circuits integer No 10 Number of random circuits (1-1000) seed integer No - Random seed for reproducibility

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "Mirror Circuits",
  "width": 10,
  "num_layers": 5,
  "two_qubit_gate_prob": 0.5,
  "two_qubit_gate_name": "CNOT",
  "shots": 1000,
  "num_circuits": 10,
  "seed": 42
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/mirror_circuits.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_sherbrooke

# Poll results
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Results
docs.text: Metric Description success_probability Average probability of returning to polarization Normalized success probability std_error Statistical uncertainty

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text: MirrorCircuitsResult(success_probability=0.85, polarization=0.70)

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Forward Half: Apply random Clifford layers respecting device connectivity
  2. Inversion: Compute and apply the inverse of the forward circuit
  3. Measurement: Measure all qubits in the computational basis
  4. Analysis: The circuit should return to |0...0⟩ on a perfect device

docs.title: Circuit Structure
docs.text: |0⟩ ─[Layer 1]─[Layer 2]─...─[Layer n]─[Layer n†]─...─[Layer 2†]─[Layer 1†]─ M → |0⟩

docs.title: num_layers
docs.text: Controls circuit depth: - Low (1-3): Quick connectivity test - Medium (5-10): Typical benchmark - High (20+): Stress test for error accumulation

docs.title: two_qubit_gate_prob
docs.text: Controls entanglement density: - 0.3: Sparse two-qubit gates - 0.5: Balanced (default) - 0.8: Dense two-qubit gates

docs.title: Interpretation
docs.text: Success Probability Polarization Interpretation > 0.9 > 0.8 Excellent fidelity 0.7 - 0.9 0.4 - 0.8 Good fidelity 0.5 - 0.7 0.0 - 0.4 Moderate errors < 0.5 < 0.0 High error rate

docs.title: Device Requirements
docs.text:
• Requires device topology for connectivity-aware circuit generation
  • Works on any gate-based quantum computer

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• arXiv:2008.11294 - Mirror Circuit Benchmarking
  • Qiskit Device Benchmarking

docs.title: Benchmarks Overview
docs.text: Metriq-Gym provides a comprehensive suite of quantum benchmarks to characterize and compare quantum hardware performance.

docs.title: Available Benchmarks
docs.text: Benchmark Category Description BSEQ Connectivity Binary Sequence - measures device connectivity CLOPS Throughput Circuit Layer Operations Per Second EPLG Error Rate Error Per Layered Gate Mirror Circuits Error Rate Randomized mirror circuit benchmarking QML Kernel Application Quantum Machine Learning kernel estimation Quantum Volume Holistic Overall device capability metric WIT Application Wormhole-Inspired Teleportation LR-QAOA Application Linear Ramp QAOA for MaxCut QED-C Benchmarks Algorithm Bernstein-Vazirani, Phase Estimation, Hidden Shift, QFT

docs.title: Connectivity Benchmarks
docs.text: Test device qubit connectivity and topology: - BSEQ: Measures the largest connected subgraph of working qubits

docs.title: Throughput Benchmarks
docs.text: Measure execution speed and efficiency: - CLOPS: Measures how many circuit layer operations can be executed per second

docs.title: Error Rate Benchmarks
docs.text: Characterize noise and error rates: - EPLG: Measures error per layered gate using randomized benchmarking - Mirror Circuits: Uses self-inverting circuits to measure total circuit fidelity

docs.title: Holistic Benchmarks
docs.text: Overall device capability metrics: - Quantum Volume: Standard metric combining qubit count and error rates

docs.title: Application Benchmarks
docs.text: Test performance on specific quantum algorithms: - WIT: Wormhole-inspired teleportation fidelity - QML Kernel: Quantum kernel estimation for machine learning - LR-QAOA: Linear ramp QAOA for combinatorial optimization

docs.title: Algorithm Benchmarks
docs.text: Standard quantum algorithm implementations: - QED-C Benchmarks: Suite including Bernstein-Vazirani, Phase Estimation, Hidden Shift, and QFT

docs.title: Configuration Format
docs.text:
All benchmarks use JSON configuration files:

{
  "benchmark_name": "Quantum Volume",
  "num_qubits": 5,
  "shots": 1000,
  "trials": 100
}

docs.title: Common Parameters
docs.text: Parameter Description benchmark_name Required benchmark identifier shots Number of measurement repetitions num_qubits Number of qubits to use

docs.title: Example Configurations
docs.text:
Pre-made configurations are available in metriq_gym/schemas/examples/:

ls metriq_gym/schemas/examples/

docs.title: Single Benchmark
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/quantum_volume.example.json \
    --provider local --device aer_simulator

docs.title: Benchmark Suite
docs.text:
Create a suite file to run multiple benchmarks:

{
  "name": "performance_suite",
  "benchmarks": [
    {"name": "qv", "config": {"benchmark_name": "Quantum Volume", "num_qubits": 5}},
    {"name": "clops", "config": {"benchmark_name": "CLOPS", "shots": 100}}
  ]
}

mgym suite dispatch suite.json --provider local --device aer_simulator

docs.title: Results Format
docs.text:
Benchmark results include:

{
  "app_version": "0.3.1",
  "provider": "ibm",
  "device": "ibm_fez",
  "job_type": "Quantum Volume",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T12:00:00Z",
  "results": {
    "values": {
      "quantum_volume": 32,
      "heavy_output_probability": 0.68
    },
    "uncertainties": {
      "heavy_output_probability": 0.02
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Uploading Results
docs.text:
Share results with the community:

mgym job upload <JOB_ID>

Results are uploaded to unitaryfoundation/metriq-data and displayed on metriq.info.

docs.title: Adding Custom Benchmarks
docs.text: See Adding New Benchmarks to contribute new benchmarks.

docs.title: QED-C Benchmarks
docs.text: The QED-C (Quantum Economic Development Consortium) benchmarks are a suite of application-oriented quantum algorithms for evaluating quantum computers.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: These benchmarks implement standard quantum algorithms and evaluate device performance across varying problem sizes. They're based on the QED-C Application-Oriented Benchmarks suite.

docs.title: Available Benchmarks
docs.text: Benchmark Description Bernstein-Vazirani Hidden string discovery Phase Estimation Eigenvalue estimation Hidden Shift Function shift discovery Quantum Fourier Transform QFT implementation

docs.title: Bernstein-Vazirani
docs.text: Finds a hidden binary string encoded in a function using a single query.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "Bernstein-Vazirani" shots integer No 1000 Measurement shots min_qubits integer No 2 Starting qubit count max_qubits integer No 6 Maximum qubit count skip_qubits integer No 1 Step size between sizes max_circuits integer No 3 Circuits per qubit count method integer No 1 QED-C method variant (1 or 2) input_value integer No - Specific secret string

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "Bernstein-Vazirani",
  "min_qubits": 4,
  "max_qubits": 8,
  "shots": 5000
}

docs.title: Phase Estimation
docs.text: Estimates the eigenvalue of a unitary operator.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "Phase Estimation" shots integer No 1000 Measurement shots min_qubits integer No 3 Starting qubit count max_qubits integer No 6 Maximum qubit count skip_qubits integer No 1 Step size between sizes max_circuits integer No 3 Circuits per qubit count init_phase float No - Initial phase theta use_midcircuit_measurement boolean No false Enable mid-circuit measurements

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "Phase Estimation",
  "min_qubits": 4,
  "max_qubits": 7,
  "shots": 5000,
  "use_midcircuit_measurement": false
}

docs.title: Hidden Shift
docs.text: Discovers a hidden shift in bent Boolean functions.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "Hidden Shift" shots integer No 1000 Measurement shots min_qubits integer No 2 Starting qubit count max_qubits integer No 6 Maximum qubit count skip_qubits integer No 1 Step size between sizes max_circuits integer No 3 Circuits per qubit count input_value integer No - Specific secret value

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "Hidden Shift",
  "min_qubits": 4,
  "max_qubits": 8,
  "shots": 5000
}

docs.title: Quantum Fourier Transform
docs.text: Implements the Quantum Fourier Transform, a key subroutine in many quantum algorithms.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "Quantum Fourier Transform" shots integer No 1000 Measurement shots min_qubits integer No 2 Starting qubit count max_qubits integer No 6 Maximum qubit count skip_qubits integer No 1 Step size between sizes max_circuits integer No 3 Circuits per qubit count method integer No 1 Method variant (1 or 2) input_value integer No - Specific input state use_midcircuit_measurement boolean No false Enable mid-circuit measurements

docs.title: Example
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "Quantum Fourier Transform",
  "min_qubits": 3,
  "max_qubits": 8,
  "shots": 5000,
  "method": 1
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
All QED-C benchmarks follow the same dispatch pattern:

# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/bernstein_vazirani.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_sherbrooke

# Poll results
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Results Format
docs.text:
QED-C benchmarks return:

Metric Description success_rate Fraction of correct answers fidelity Circuit execution fidelity qubit_scaling Performance vs. qubit count

docs.title: Scaling Analysis
docs.text:
These benchmarks are designed to test scaling:

{
  "benchmark_name": "Bernstein-Vazirani",
  "min_qubits": 4,
  "max_qubits": 20,
  "skip_qubits": 2
}

This runs at 4, 6, 8, 10, 12, 14, 16, 18, and 20 qubits.

docs.title: Method Variants
docs.text: Some benchmarks support multiple implementation methods: - Method 1: Standard textbook implementation - Method 2: Alternative or optimized implementation

docs.title: Mid-Circuit Measurements
docs.text:
Phase Estimation and QFT support iterative versions with mid-circuit measurements:

{
  "benchmark_name": "Phase Estimation",
  "use_midcircuit_measurement": true
}

Note

Mid-circuit measurements require hardware support. Check provider documentation.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• QED-C Application-Oriented Benchmarks
  • arXiv:2110.03137 - Application-Oriented Performance Benchmarks

docs.title: QML Kernel
docs.text: The QML Kernel benchmark measures a device's ability to estimate quantum kernel functions for machine learning applications.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Quantum kernels are a key primitive in quantum machine learning (QML). This benchmark evaluates a device's accuracy in computing kernel matrix elements, which are used in support vector machines and other kernel-based algorithms.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "QML Kernel" num_qubits integer Yes - Number of qubits (min: 2) shots integer No 1000 Measurement shots

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "QML Kernel",
  "num_qubits": 10,
  "shots": 1000
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/qml_kernel.example.json \
    --provider local --device aer_simulator

# Poll results
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Results
docs.text: Metric Description kernel_accuracy Accuracy of kernel estimation fidelity State preparation fidelity

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text: QMLKernelResult(kernel_accuracy=0.95, fidelity=0.98)

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Feature Map: Encode classical data into quantum states using a feature map circuit
  2. Kernel Computation: Measure overlap between encoded states
  3. Comparison: Compare hardware results to ideal kernel values
  4. Scoring: Calculate accuracy metrics

docs.title: Kernel Formula
docs.text:
The quantum kernel is computed as:

K(x, x') = |⟨φ(x)|φ(x')⟩|²

Where φ(x) is the quantum feature map encoding classical data x.

docs.title: Feature Maps
docs.text:
The benchmark uses a ZZ feature map by default:

|0⟩ ─ H ─ U(x) ─ ZZ(x) ─ ... ─ M

docs.title: Interpretation
docs.text: Kernel Accuracy Interpretation > 0.95 Excellent for QML applications 0.85 - 0.95 Good accuracy 0.70 - 0.85 Moderate - may impact ML performance < 0.70 Poor - consider error mitigation

docs.title: Use Cases
docs.text: This benchmark is relevant for: - Quantum Support Vector Machines (QSVM) - Quantum kernel regression - Quantum feature space analysis - Comparing devices for QML tasks

docs.title: Scaling Considerations
docs.text:
Qubits Feature Dimension Typical Circuits 4 16 ~10 8 256 ~50 12 4096 ~200

Warning

Kernel matrix computation scales quadratically with dataset size. Use modest qubit counts for initial testing.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• arXiv:1804.11326 - Quantum Machine Learning
  • arXiv:2101.11020 - Power of Quantum Kernels

docs.title: Quantum Volume
docs.text: Quantum Volume is a holistic benchmark that measures the largest square circuit a device can reliably execute.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Quantum Volume (QV) is IBM's standard metric for overall quantum computer capability. A device achieves QV = 2^n if it can successfully run random n-qubit circuits with depth n. The metric captures: - Qubit count - Connectivity - Gate fidelity - Measurement fidelity - Crosstalk

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "Quantum Volume" num_qubits integer Yes - Number of qubits to test (min: 1) shots integer No 1000 Shots per circuit trials integer No 100 Number of random circuits confidence_level float No 0.95 Statistical confidence (0-1)

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "Quantum Volume",
  "num_qubits": 5,
  "shots": 1000,
  "trials": 100,
  "confidence_level": 0.95
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/quantum_volume.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_sherbrooke

# Poll results
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Results
docs.text: Metric Description quantum_volume Achieved QV (2^n if successful) heavy_output_probability Fraction of heavy outputs success Whether QV threshold was met confidence_interval Statistical bounds

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text: QuantumVolumeResult(quantum_volume=32, heavy_output_probability=0.68, success=True)

docs.title: Success Criteria
docs.text: QV is achieved at level 2^n if: 1. Heavy output probability > 2/3 (66.7%) 2. Statistical confidence ≥ specified level (default 95%)

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
1. Circuit Generation: Create random SU(4) layers on n qubits
  2. Simulation: Classically compute ideal output distribution
  3. Heavy Outputs: Identify bitstrings with above-median probability
  4. Execution: Run circuits on hardware
  5. Analysis: Count fraction of heavy outputs measured

docs.title: Interpretation
docs.text: Quantum Volume Interpretation 2 Minimal 1-qubit operation 8-16 Early quantum advantage regime 32-64 Current mid-range devices 128-256 High-end devices (2024-2025) 512+ Target for error-corrected systems

docs.title: Testing Strategy
docs.text:
Start with lower qubit counts and increase:

# Test QV = 8 (3 qubits)
mgym job dispatch qv_3.json -p ibm -d ibm_sherbrooke

# Test QV = 16 (4 qubits)
mgym job dispatch qv_4.json -p ibm -d ibm_sherbrooke

# Test QV = 32 (5 qubits)
mgym job dispatch qv_5.json -p ibm -d ibm_sherbrooke

docs.title: Statistical Requirements
docs.text: For reliable QV claims: - trials: Minimum 100 (200 recommended for publications) - shots: Minimum 1000 per circuit - confidence_level: 0.95 or higher

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• arXiv:1811.12926 - Validating quantum computers using randomized model circuits
  • IBM Quantum: What is Quantum Volume?

docs.title: WIT (Wormhole-Inspired Teleportation)
docs.text: The WIT benchmark tests quantum teleportation fidelity inspired by traversable wormhole physics.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Wormhole-Inspired Teleportation (WIT) implements a quantum teleportation protocol based on the SYK model, which has connections to traversable wormhole physics in AdS/CFT correspondence. The benchmark measures how well a device can perform this specific teleportation task.

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text: Parameter Type Required Default Description benchmark_name string Yes - Must be "WIT" num_qubits integer No 6 Number of qubits (6 or 7 only) shots integer No 1000 Measurement shots

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
{
  "benchmark_name": "WIT",
  "num_qubits": 7,
  "shots": 8192
}

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider local --device aer_simulator

# Poll results
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Results
docs.text: Metric Description expectation_value Teleportation fidelity (ideal = 1.0)

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text: WITResult(expectation_value=0.9970703125)

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
The WIT protocol:

  1. Preparation: Create an entangled state between "left" and "right" subsystems
  2. Encoding: Encode information on the left side
  3. Interaction: Apply a coupling operation between subsystems
  4. Teleportation: Information appears on the right side
  5. Measurement: Verify successful teleportation via expectation value

docs.title: Circuit Structure
docs.text:
The WIT circuit uses either 6 or 7 qubits:

  • 6 qubits: Minimal implementation
  • 7 qubits: Extended version with ancilla

docs.title: Qubit Selection
docs.text: num_qubits Structure 6 3 left + 3 right qubits 7 3 left + 3 right + 1 ancilla

docs.title: Interpretation
docs.text: Expectation Value Interpretation > 0.95 Excellent teleportation fidelity 0.85 - 0.95 Good fidelity 0.70 - 0.85 Moderate fidelity < 0.70 Poor fidelity - high error rates

docs.title: Ideal vs. Real Performance
docs.text: Device Type Typical Result Ideal simulator 1.0 Noisy simulator 0.95-0.99 Current hardware 0.70-0.95

docs.title: Physics Background
docs.text:
The benchmark is based on: - The Sachdev-Ye-Kitaev (SYK) model - Traversable wormhole protocols in AdS/CFT - Quantum teleportation enhanced by scrambling dynamics

The protocol demonstrates that information can be "teleported" through an Einstein-Rosen bridge analog in the quantum circuit.

docs.title: References
docs.text:
• arXiv:2205.14081 - Wormhole-Inspired Teleportation
  • Nature 612, 51-55 (2022) - Traversable wormhole dynamics on a quantum processor

docs.title: Resource Estimation
docs.text: Estimate circuit resource requirements before dispatching jobs. This is especially useful for understanding costs on paid hardware like Quantinuum.

docs.title: estimate
docs.text:
Approximate the circuit footprint, gate counts, and (for Quantinuum) HQCs before running a job.

mgym job estimate <config_file> --provider <provider> [--device <device>]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description config_file Path to benchmark configuration JSON file

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Description --provider -p Provider name (required) --device -d Device identifier (required for some benchmarks)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Basic estimation
mgym job estimate metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider quantinuum

# With device (required for topology-dependent benchmarks)
mgym job estimate metriq_gym/schemas/examples/bseq.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_fez

docs.title: Quantinuum HQC Estimation
docs.text:
For Quantinuum providers, the estimator calculates H-series Quantum Credits (HQCs) using the published formula:

HQC = 5 + C * (N1 + 10*N2 + 5*Nm) / 5000

Where: - C = number of shots - N1 = single-qubit gate count - N2 = two-qubit gate count - Nm = measurement count

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
Resource Estimation for WIT benchmark
=====================================

Circuits: 1
Total shots: 8192

Per-circuit statistics:
+----------+--------+----------+----------+-------+
| Circuit  | Qubits | 1Q Gates | 2Q Gates | Meas  |
+==========+========+==========+==========+=======+
| wit_0    | 7      | 42       | 28       | 7     |
+----------+--------+----------+----------+-------+

Aggregated totals:
- Total 1Q gates: 42
- Total 2Q gates: 28
- Total measurements: 7

Quantinuum HQC estimate: 52.4

docs.title: Device-Dependent Benchmarks
docs.text:
Some benchmarks require device topology information for accurate estimation:

Benchmark Requires Device BSEQ Yes CLOPS Yes Mirror Circuits Yes LR-QAOA Yes EPLG No Quantum Volume No WIT No QML Kernel No

For these benchmarks, supply --device so the estimator can inspect connectivity:

mgym job estimate metriq_gym/schemas/examples/mirror_circuits.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_sherbrooke

docs.title: Cost Planning
docs.text:
Before running expensive hardware jobs:

# Estimate Quantinuum costs
mgym job estimate my_benchmark.json -p quantinuum

# Output shows HQC estimate for budgeting

docs.title: Benchmark Comparison
docs.text:
Compare resource requirements across benchmarks:

# Compare EPLG vs Mirror Circuits
mgym job estimate metriq_gym/schemas/examples/eplg.example.json -p ibm -d ibm_fez
mgym job estimate metriq_gym/schemas/examples/mirror_circuits.example.json -p ibm -d ibm_fez

docs.title: Configuration Tuning
docs.text:
Adjust shots or qubit counts to fit within budget:

# Original: high shot count
mgym job estimate high_shots.json -p quantinuum

# Modified: reduced shots
mgym job estimate low_shots.json -p quantinuum

docs.title: Job Commands
docs.text: Commands for dispatching, monitoring, and managing individual benchmark jobs.

docs.title: dispatch
docs.text:
Dispatch a benchmark job to a quantum device or simulator.

mgym job dispatch <config_file> --provider <provider> --device <device>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description config_file Path to benchmark configuration JSON file

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Description --provider -p Provider name (required) --device -d Device identifier (required)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Run on local simulator
mgym job dispatch wit.example.json -p local -d aer_simulator

# Run on IBM hardware
mgym job dispatch wit.example.json -p ibm -d ibm_fez

# Run with noise model simulation
mgym job dispatch qml_kernel.example.json -p local -d ibm_sherbrooke

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Starting dispatch on ibm:ibm_sherbrooke...
Dispatching BSEQ benchmark from bseq.example.json on ibm_sherbrooke...
Job dispatched with ID: 93a06a18-41d8-475a-a030-339fbf3accb9

docs.title: poll
docs.text:
Poll job status and retrieve results when complete.

mgym job poll [job_id]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description job_id Metriq-Gym job ID (optional; interactive if omitted)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Description --json Export results to JSON file latest Poll the most recently dispatched job

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Poll specific job
mgym job poll 93a06a18-41d8-475a-a030-339fbf3accb9

# Poll latest job
mgym job poll latest

# Interactive selection
mgym job poll

# Export to JSON
mgym job poll 93a06a18-41d8-475a-a030-339fbf3accb9 --json

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
When complete: 

Polling job...
BSEQResult(largest_connected_size=100, fraction_connected=0.7874)

When queued: 

Job is queued at position 5. Please try again later.

docs.title: view
docs.text:
View job details and metadata.

mgym job view [job_id]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description job_id Metriq-Gym job ID (optional; lists all if omitted)

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# View all jobs
mgym job view

# View specific job
mgym job view 93a06a18-41d8-475a-a030-339fbf3accb9

docs.title: upload
docs.text:
Upload job results to GitHub via pull request.

mgym job upload <job_id>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description job_id Metriq-Gym job ID (required)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Environment Variable Default --repo MGYM_UPLOAD_REPO unitaryfoundation/metriq-data --dir MGYM_UPLOAD_DIR metriq-gym/v<version>/<provider>/<device>

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Set a GitHub token with repo permissions:

export GITHUB_TOKEN="your-token-here"

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Upload with defaults
mgym job upload 93a06a18-41d8-475a-a030-339fbf3accb9

# Upload to custom repository
mgym job upload 93a06a18-41d8-475a-a030-339fbf3accb9 --repo myorg/my-data

docs.title: Output
docs.text: The command creates a pull request and returns the PR URL. Files are named using the pattern <timestamp>_<benchmark>_<hash>.json.

docs.title: delete
docs.text:
Delete a job from the local database.

mgym job delete <job_id>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text:
Argument Description job_id Metriq-Gym job ID (required)

Note

This only removes the job from the local tracking database. It does not cancel jobs running on quantum hardware.

docs.title: CLI Overview
docs.text: Metriq-Gym provides the mgym command-line interface for dispatching, monitoring, and managing benchmark jobs.

docs.title: Command Structure
docs.text:
mgym <resource> <action> [options]

Resources: - job - Single benchmark operations - suite - Benchmark suite operations

docs.title: Job Commands
docs.text: Command Description mgym job dispatch <config> Dispatch a benchmark job mgym job poll [job_id] Poll job status and retrieve results mgym job view [job_id] View job details mgym job upload <job_id> Upload results to GitHub mgym job estimate <config> Estimate resource usage

docs.title: Suite Commands
docs.text: Command Description mgym suite dispatch <suite.json> Dispatch all benchmarks in a suite mgym suite poll [suite_id] Poll suite status mgym suite upload <suite_id> Upload all suite results

docs.title: Global Options
docs.text: Option Description --provider, -p Provider name (ibm, ionq, braket, azure, quantinuum, origin, local) --device, -d Device identifier --help, -h Show help message

docs.title: Interactive Mode
docs.text:
When job or suite IDs are omitted, commands enter interactive mode:

# Lists all jobs and prompts for selection
mgym job poll

# Lists all jobs for viewing
mgym job view

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
Configure default behavior via environment variables or .env file:

Variable Description MGYM_LOCAL_DB_DIR Directory for job database MGYM_LOCAL_SIMULATOR_CACHE_DIR Cache directory for simulator results GITHUB_TOKEN Token for GitHub uploads MGYM_UPLOAD_REPO Default upload repository

See Provider Configuration for provider-specific variables.

docs.title: Local Job Database
docs.text:
The CLI maintains a local job database (.metriq_gym_jobs.jsonl) to track jobs between dispatch and poll operations.

Warning

The local database is meant as a transient queue, not archival storage. Export results regularly or back up the file if you need to retain history.

Database location: - Custom: Set MGYM_LOCAL_DB_DIR - Default: Platform-specific user data directory (e.g., ~/Library/Application Support/metriq-gym on macOS)

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• Job Commands - Detailed job command reference
  • Suite Commands - Working with benchmark suites
  • Resource Estimation - Estimating job costs

docs.title: Suite Commands
docs.text: Commands for working with benchmark suites - collections of multiple benchmarks run together.

docs.title: Suite Configuration
docs.text:
Suites are defined in JSON files that specify multiple benchmarks:

{
  "name": "my_test_suite",
  "description": "A collection of benchmarks for testing",
  "benchmarks": [
    {
      "name": "BSEQ",
      "config": {
        "benchmark_name": "BSEQ",
        "shots": 10
      }
    },
    {
      "name": "wit_7_qubits",
      "config": {
        "benchmark_name": "WIT",
        "num_qubits": 7,
        "shots": 1000
      }
    },
    {
      "name": "quantum_volume_5",
      "config": {
        "benchmark_name": "Quantum Volume",
        "num_qubits": 5,
        "shots": 1000
      }
    }
  ]
}

docs.title: Suite Fields
docs.text: Field Description name Suite identifier description Optional description benchmarks Array of benchmark configurations

docs.title: Benchmark Entry Fields
docs.text: Field Description name Unique name within the suite config Benchmark configuration (same as standalone JSON files)

docs.title: dispatch
docs.text:
Dispatch all benchmarks in a suite.

mgym suite dispatch <suite.json> --provider <provider> --device <device>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description suite.json Path to suite configuration file

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Option Short Description --provider -p Provider name (required) --device -d Device identifier (required)

docs.title: Example
docs.text: mgym suite dispatch my_suite.json -p ibm -d ibm_fez

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Starting suite dispatch on ibm:ibm_fez...
Dispatching BSEQ...
Dispatching wit_7_qubits...
Dispatching quantum_volume_5...
Suite dispatched with ID: a1b2c3d4-5678-90ab-cdef-1234567890ab

docs.title: poll
docs.text:
Poll suite status and retrieve results for all benchmarks.

mgym suite poll [suite_id]

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description suite_id Metriq-Gym suite ID (optional; interactive if omitted)

docs.title: Example
docs.text: mgym suite poll a1b2c3d4-5678-90ab-cdef-1234567890ab

docs.title: Output
docs.text:
Displays status for each benchmark in the suite:

Suite: my_test_suite
+------------------+----------+--------------------------+
| Benchmark        | Status   | Result                   |
+==================+==========+==========================+
| BSEQ             | complete | fraction_connected=0.78  |
| wit_7_qubits     | complete | expectation_value=0.95   |
| quantum_volume_5 | queued   | -                        |
+------------------+----------+--------------------------+

docs.title: upload
docs.text:
Upload all suite results to GitHub.

mgym suite upload <suite_id>

docs.title: Arguments
docs.text: Argument Description suite_id Metriq-Gym suite ID (required)

docs.title: Options
docs.text: Same as mgym job upload - see Job Commands.

docs.title: Example
docs.text: mgym suite upload a1b2c3d4-5678-90ab-cdef-1234567890ab

docs.title: Output
docs.text: Creates a single pull request containing all benchmark results from the suite.

docs.title: Adding New Benchmarks
docs.text: This guide explains how to integrate a new benchmark into Metriq-Gym.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Adding a benchmark involves:

  1. Creating Python classes (Benchmark, Data, Result)
  2. Defining a JSON Schema for configuration
  3. Providing an example configuration
  4. Registering the benchmark in the system

docs.title: Step 1: Create the Benchmark Class
docs.text:
Create a new file in metriq_gym/benchmarks/:

# metriq_gym/benchmarks/my_benchmark.py

from dataclasses import dataclass
from qbraid.runtime import QuantumDevice, GateModelResultData

from metriq_gym.benchmarks.benchmark import (
    Benchmark,
    BenchmarkData,
    BenchmarkResult,
    BenchmarkScore,
)


@dataclass
class MyBenchmarkResult(BenchmarkResult):
    """Stores the results from running My Benchmark."""

    # Simple numeric metric
    success_rate: float

    # Metric with uncertainty
    fidelity: BenchmarkScore


@dataclass
class MyBenchmarkData(BenchmarkData):
    """Stores intermediate data for My Benchmark."""

    # Data needed between dispatch and poll
    expected_outputs: list[str]
    num_circuits: int


class MyBenchmark(Benchmark):
    """Benchmark implementation for My Benchmark."""

    def dispatch_handler(self, device: QuantumDevice) -> MyBenchmarkData:
        """Create and submit benchmark circuits.

        Args:
            device: The quantum device to run on

        Returns:
            Data needed for result analysis
        """
        # Access configuration via self.config
        num_qubits = self.config.get("num_qubits", 5)
        shots = self.config.get("shots", 1000)

        # Create circuits
        circuits = self._create_circuits(num_qubits)

        # Submit to device (handled by base class)
        # Just return the circuits and metadata

        return MyBenchmarkData(
            expected_outputs=["00000"] * len(circuits),
            num_circuits=len(circuits),
        )

    def poll_handler(
        self,
        job_data: BenchmarkData,
        result_data: list[GateModelResultData]
    ) -> MyBenchmarkResult:
        """Process results and compute metrics.

        Args:
            job_data: Data from dispatch phase
            result_data: Raw measurement results

        Returns:
            Computed benchmark results
        """
        data = job_data  # Cast to MyBenchmarkData

        # Analyze results
        successes = 0
        for i, result in enumerate(result_data):
            counts = result.measurements
            if data.expected_outputs[i] in counts:
                successes += counts[data.expected_outputs[i]]

        total_shots = sum(sum(r.measurements.values()) for r in result_data)
        success_rate = successes / total_shots

        # Calculate fidelity with uncertainty
        fidelity_val = self._calculate_fidelity(result_data)
        fidelity_unc = self._calculate_uncertainty(result_data)

        return MyBenchmarkResult(
            success_rate=success_rate,
            fidelity=BenchmarkScore(value=fidelity_val, uncertainty=fidelity_unc),
        )

    def _create_circuits(self, num_qubits: int):
        """Create benchmark circuits."""
        # Implementation details...
        pass

    def _calculate_fidelity(self, results):
        """Calculate fidelity metric."""
        pass

    def _calculate_uncertainty(self, results):
        """Calculate statistical uncertainty."""
        pass

docs.title: Step 2: Define the JSON Schema
docs.text:
Create metriq_gym/schemas/my_benchmark.schema.json:

{
  "$id": "metriq-gym/my_benchmark.schema.json",
  "$schema": "https://json-schema.org/draft/2020-12/schema",
  "title": "My Benchmark",
  "description": "Schema for My Benchmark configuration.",
  "type": "object",
  "properties": {
    "benchmark_name": {
      "type": "string",
      "const": "My Benchmark",
      "description": "Must be 'My Benchmark'"
    },
    "num_qubits": {
      "type": "integer",
      "description": "Number of qubits to use",
      "minimum": 1,
      "examples": [5]
    },
    "shots": {
      "type": "integer",
      "description": "Measurement shots per circuit",
      "default": 1000,
      "minimum": 1,
      "examples": [1000]
    },
    "custom_param": {
      "type": "number",
      "description": "A custom parameter for this benchmark",
      "default": 0.5,
      "minimum": 0.0,
      "maximum": 1.0
    }
  },
  "required": ["benchmark_name", "num_qubits"]
}

docs.title: Step 3: Create Example Configuration
docs.text:
Create metriq_gym/schemas/examples/my_benchmark.example.json:

{
  "benchmark_name": "My Benchmark",
  "num_qubits": 5,
  "shots": 1000,
  "custom_param": 0.5
}

docs.title: Add to constants.py
docs.text:
# metriq_gym/constants.py

class JobType(StrEnum):
    # ... existing entries ...
    MY_BENCHMARK = "My Benchmark"


SCHEMA_MAPPING = {
    # ... existing entries ...
    JobType.MY_BENCHMARK: "my_benchmark.schema.json",
}

docs.title: Add to registry.py
docs.text:
# metriq_gym/registry.py

from metriq_gym.benchmarks.my_benchmark import MyBenchmark, MyBenchmarkData

BENCHMARK_HANDLERS: dict[JobType, type[Benchmark]] = {
    # ... existing entries ...
    JobType.MY_BENCHMARK: MyBenchmark,
}

BENCHMARK_DATA_CLASSES: dict[JobType, type[BenchmarkData]] = {
    # ... existing entries ...
    JobType.MY_BENCHMARK: MyBenchmarkData,
}

docs.title: Simple Numeric Metrics
docs.text:
For metrics without uncertainty:

@dataclass
class MyResult(BenchmarkResult):
    score: float  # No uncertainty

docs.title: Metrics with Uncertainty
docs.text:
For metrics with statistical uncertainty:

@dataclass
class MyResult(BenchmarkResult):
    fidelity: BenchmarkScore  # Has value and uncertainty

Usage: 

return MyResult(
    fidelity=BenchmarkScore(value=0.95, uncertainty=0.02)
)

docs.title: Result Export
docs.text:
The exporter automatically creates:

{
  "results": {
    "values": {
      "score": 0.85,
      "fidelity": 0.95
    },
    "uncertainties": {
      "fidelity": 0.02
    }
  }
}

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
• Use sensible defaults for optional parameters
  • Validate parameters in dispatch_handler
  • Document all parameters in the schema

docs.title: Circuit Creation
docs.text:
• Use Qiskit circuits for portability
  • Respect device topology when possible
  • Keep circuits transpiler-friendly

docs.title: Result Analysis
docs.text:
• Calculate meaningful uncertainty estimates
  • Handle edge cases (zero shots, failed circuits)
  • Return None for undefined metrics

docs.title: Testing
docs.text:
Create tests in tests/test_benchmarks.py:

def test_my_benchmark_dispatch():
    config = {"benchmark_name": "My Benchmark", "num_qubits": 5}
    benchmark = MyBenchmark(config)
    data = benchmark.dispatch_handler(mock_device)
    assert data.num_circuits > 0

def test_my_benchmark_poll():
    # Test result processing
    ...

docs.title: Checklist
docs.text:
Before submitting your benchmark:

  • [ ] Benchmark class implements dispatch_handler and poll_handler
  • [ ] JSON Schema validates all configuration options
  • [ ] Example configuration works with local simulator
  • [ ] Benchmark registered in constants.py and registry.py
  • [ ] Tests cover dispatch and poll logic
  • [ ] Documentation explains benchmark purpose and metrics

docs.title: API Reference
docs.text: This page documents the main Python modules in Metriq-Gym.

docs.title: metriq_gym.run
docs.text:
Main runtime module with dispatch, poll, and upload functions.

Runtime entrypoints for dispatching and managing metriq-gym benchmarks via the CLI.

docs.title: dispatch_job(args, job_manager)
docs.text:
Dispatch a single benchmark configuration to a quantum device.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default args Namespace

CLI arguments with benchmark config, provider, and device

required job_manager JobManager

Tracks dispatched jobs for later polling

required

Note: Continues processing remaining configs if individual configs fail.

docs.title: upload_job(args, job_manager)
docs.text: Upload a job's results to a GitHub repo by opening a Pull Request.

docs.title: load_provider(provider_name)
docs.text:
Lazy proxy to qbraid.runtime.load_provider.

Exposed at module level so tests can monkeypatch metriq_gym.run.load_provider.

docs.title: setup_device(provider_name, device_name)
docs.text:
Setup a QBraid device with id device_name from specified provider.

Parameters:

Name Type Description Default provider_name str

a metriq-gym supported provider name.

required device_name str

the id of a device supported by the provider.

required

Raises: QBraidSetupError: If no device matching the name is found in the provider.

docs.title: metriq_gym.cli
docs.text:
Command-line interface utilities.

Command-line parsing for running Metriq-Gym benchmarks.

Usage overview
  • Dispatch a single job: mgym job dispatch path/to/config.json -p -d
  • Poll latest job and write JSON results: mgym job poll latest --json results.json
  • Dispatch a suite of jobs: mgym suite dispatch path/to/suite.json -p -d
  • Poll a suite: mgym suite poll
  • Dry-run upload (no network): mgym job upload latest --dry-run

docs.title: build_parser()
docs.text:
Parse command-line arguments for the metriq-gym benchmarking CLI.

This function sets up the complete argument parsing structure for metriq-gym, supporting dispatch of multiple benchmark configuration files for comprehensive device characterization.

Returns:

Type Description ArgumentParser

Parsed arguments as an argparse.Namespace object containing all CLI options.

Dispatch mode
  • Multiple benchmarks: Requires one or more JSON configuration files
  • Each file can contain different parameters for any benchmark type
  • Same benchmark type can be run multiple times with different configurations

Name Type Description Default jobs list[MetriqGymJob]

required show_index bool
