docs.title: JobManager
docs.text:
Manages job lifecycle and persistence.

from metriq_gym.job_manager import JobManager

manager = JobManager()

# Get all jobs
jobs = manager.get_jobs()

# Get specific job
job = manager.get_job("job-id")

# Add a new job
manager.add_job(job)

# Update job status
manager.update_job(job)

docs.title: MetriqGymJob
docs.text:
Represents a benchmark job.

from metriq_gym.job_manager import MetriqGymJob

job = MetriqGymJob(
    id="unique-id",
    job_type=JobType.QUANTUM_VOLUME,
    params={"num_qubits": 5, "shots": 1000},
    provider_name="ibm",
    device_name="ibm_sherbrooke",
    provider_job_ids=["remote-job-id"],
    dispatch_time="2025-01-15T12:00:00",
    app_version="0.3.1",
)

docs.title: Benchmark
docs.text:
Base class for all benchmarks.

from metriq_gym.benchmarks.benchmark import Benchmark

class MyBenchmark(Benchmark):
    def dispatch_handler(self, device):
        # Create and submit circuits
        pass

    def poll_handler(self, job_data, result_data):
        # Process results
        pass

docs.title: BenchmarkResult
docs.text:
Base class for benchmark results.

from dataclasses import dataclass
from metriq_gym.benchmarks.benchmark import BenchmarkResult

@dataclass
class MyResult(BenchmarkResult):
    metric_value: float

docs.title: BenchmarkScore
docs.text:
Metric with uncertainty.

from metriq_gym.benchmarks.benchmark import BenchmarkScore

score = BenchmarkScore(value=0.95, uncertainty=0.02)

docs.title: GitHubPRExporter
docs.text:
Exports results to GitHub via pull request.

from metriq_gym.exporters.github_pr_exporter import GitHubPRExporter

exporter = GitHubPRExporter(job, result)
pr_url = exporter.export(
    repo="unitaryfoundation/metriq-data",
    base_branch="main",
    directory="results/",
)

docs.title: JSONExporter
docs.text:
Exports results to local JSON file.

from metriq_gym.exporters.json_exporter import JSONExporter

exporter = JSONExporter(job, result)
exporter.export(output_path="result.json")

docs.title: JobType
docs.text:
Enum of supported benchmark types.

from metriq_gym.constants import JobType

JobType.QUANTUM_VOLUME  # "Quantum Volume"
JobType.CLOPS           # "CLOPS"
JobType.BSEQ            # "BSEQ"
JobType.WIT             # "WIT"
# ... etc

docs.title: SCHEMA_MAPPING
docs.text:
Maps JobType to schema files.

from metriq_gym.constants import SCHEMA_MAPPING

schema_file = SCHEMA_MAPPING[JobType.QUANTUM_VOLUME]
# "quantum_volume.schema.json"

docs.title: Dispatch and Poll
docs.text:
from types import SimpleNamespace
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from metriq_gym.run import dispatch_job, poll_job
from metriq_gym.job_manager import JobManager

load_dotenv()
job_manager = JobManager()

# Dispatch
dispatch_config = SimpleNamespace(
    config="metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json",
    provider="local",
    device="aer_simulator",
)
dispatch_job(dispatch_config, job_manager)

# Poll
jobs = job_manager.get_jobs()
poll_config = SimpleNamespace(job_id=jobs[-1].id)
poll_job(poll_config, job_manager)

docs.title: Custom Provider Setup
docs.text:
from metriq_gym.run import load_provider, setup_device

# Load provider
provider = load_provider("ibm")

# Get device
device = setup_device("ibm", "ibm_sherbrooke")

# List available devices
devices = provider.get_devices()
for d in devices:
    print(f"{d.id}: {d.status}")

docs.title: Working with Results
docs.text:
from metriq_gym.job_manager import JobManager

manager = JobManager()
job = manager.get_job("job-id")

# Access result data
if job.result_data:
    print(job.result_data)

docs.title: Developer Guide
docs.text: This guide covers setting up a development environment for contributing to Metriq-Gym.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before you begin, ensure you have:

  • Python (version 3.12 or newer)
  • uv for dependency management
  • Git for version control

docs.title: Clone the Repository
docs.text:
Clone with submodules:

git clone --recurse-submodules https://github.com/unitaryfoundation/metriq-gym.git
cd metriq-gym

If you already have a clone, update it:

git pull --recurse-submodules

docs.title: Install Dependencies
docs.text:
Install all dependencies including dev tools:

uv sync --all-groups

This creates a virtual environment in .venv and installs all dependencies.

docs.title: Activate Environment
docs.text:
Either activate the virtual environment:

source .venv/bin/activate

Or use uv run for isolated commands:

uv run pytest

docs.title: macOS Note
docs.text:
macOS users installing optional pyqpanda3 support must install libidn2:

brew reinstall libidn2

Install this before running uv sync to avoid build errors.

docs.title: Pre-commit Hooks
docs.text:
Install pre-commit hooks after cloning:

uv run pre-commit install

This runs linting and formatting automatically on each commit.

docs.title: Running Tests
docs.text:
# All tests
uv run pytest

# Unit tests only
uv run pytest -m "not e2e"

# End-to-end tests only
uv run pytest -m e2e

# Specific test file
uv run pytest tests/test_benchmarks.py

docs.title: Linting and Formatting
docs.text:
# Run ruff linter
uv run ruff check .

# Run ruff formatter
uv run ruff format .

# Check types with mypy
uv run mypy

docs.title: Building Documentation
docs.text:
cd docs
uv run mkdocs serve

Open http://127.0.0.1:8000 to view the documentation locally.

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
metriq-gym/
├── metriq_gym/
│   ├── benchmarks/      # Benchmark implementations
│   ├── exporters/       # Result export (JSON, GitHub PR)
│   ├── local/           # Local simulator provider
│   ├── origin/          # OriginQ provider
│   ├── quantinuum/      # Quantinuum provider
│   ├── schemas/         # JSON schemas and examples
│   ├── cli.py           # CLI argument parsing
│   ├── constants.py     # JobType enum, schema mapping
│   ├── job_manager.py   # Job tracking
│   ├── registry.py      # Benchmark registration
│   └── run.py           # Main entrypoint
├── tests/               # Test suite
├── docs/                # Documentation
├── submodules/          # External dependencies
└── pyproject.toml       # Project configuration

docs.title: Contribution Workflow
docs.text:
1. Fork the repository
  2. Create a feature branch
  3. Make your changes
  4. Run tests and linting
  5. Submit a pull request

docs.title: Commit Style
docs.text:
Follow Conventional Commits:

feat: add support for new benchmark type
fix: correct quantum volume calculation
docs: update provider setup guide
refactor: simplify job manager interface

docs.title: Pull Request Guidelines
docs.text:
• Rebase onto the latest main before opening a PR
  • Link related issues or discussions
  • Include CLI output or screenshots for user-facing changes
  • Ensure all tests pass
  • Get approval from maintainers

docs.title: Code Style
docs.text: The project uses: - Ruff for linting and formatting - mypy for type checking - Line length: 100 characters

docs.title: Type Annotations
docs.text:
Use type annotations for all public functions:

def dispatch_job(config: SimpleNamespace, job_manager: JobManager) -> str:
    """Dispatch a benchmark job.

    Args:
        config: Job configuration with provider, device, and config path
        job_manager: Job tracking instance

    Returns:
        The metriq-gym job ID
    """
    ...

docs.title: Test Categories
docs.text: Marker Description (none) Unit tests (fast, no external dependencies) e2e End-to-end tests (may require credentials)

docs.title: Writing Tests
docs.text:
import pytest
from metriq_gym.benchmarks.wit import WIT

def test_wit_dispatch():
    """Test WIT benchmark dispatch creates correct circuits."""
    benchmark = WIT(config)
    result = benchmark.dispatch_handler(mock_device)
    assert result.circuits is not None

@pytest.mark.e2e
def test_wit_full_workflow():
    """Test full WIT workflow on simulator."""
    # This test requires local simulator
    ...

docs.title: Verbose Logging
docs.text:
Enable debug logging:

import logging
logging.basicConfig(level=logging.DEBUG)

docs.title: Local Testing
docs.text:
Test against the local simulator:

mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    -p local -d aer_simulator

docs.title: Release Process
docs.text:
Releases are managed by maintainers:

  1. Version is determined by setuptools_scm from git tags
  2. CI builds and publishes to PyPI
  3. Documentation is deployed to GitHub Pages

docs.title: Getting Help
docs.text:
• Issue Tracker
  • Discussions
  • CONTRIBUTING.md

docs.title: Quickstart
docs.text: Metriq-Gym provides a command-line interface for running quantum benchmark jobs on simulators and hardware. This guide focuses on the essentials so you can submit your first job quickly.

docs.title: Installation
docs.text:
Install the package from PyPI:

pip install metriq-gym

docs.title: 1. Download an Example Configuration
docs.text:
Download an example configuration file for the WIT (Wormhole-inspired teleportation) benchmark:

curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/unitaryfoundation/metriq-gym/main/metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json

Note

Example configurations for all benchmarks are available in the metriq_gym/schemas/examples/ directory.

docs.title: 2. Dispatch the Benchmark
docs.text:
Run the benchmark on the local Aer simulator:

mgym job dispatch wit.example.json -p local -d aer_simulator

This command dispatches the job and returns a job ID that you'll use to check results.

docs.title: 3. Poll for Results
docs.text:
Check the status and retrieve results:

mgym job poll latest

If the job completed, metrics such as expectation values are reported in your terminal.

Tip

Use mgym job poll without arguments to choose from recent jobs interactively.

docs.title: Configuration Files
docs.text:
Each benchmark is configured via JSON documents. The metriq_gym/schemas/examples/ directory contains ready-to-run templates for all supported benchmarks. Customize a copy to:

  • Switch benchmarks (change benchmark_name)
  • Adjust qubit counts or shots
  • Supply provider-specific options

Example WIT configuration:

{
  "benchmark_name": "WIT",
  "num_qubits": 7,
  "shots": 8192
}

docs.title: Running on Real Hardware
docs.text:
To run benchmarks on cloud quantum hardware:

  1. Set up provider credentials in a .env file (see Provider Configuration)
  2. Specify the provider and device:
mgym job dispatch wit.example.json --provider ibm --device ibm_fez

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• End-to-End Tutorial - Complete walkthrough including uploading results
  • CLI Reference - All available commands
  • Provider Configuration - Setup guides for each provider
  • Benchmarks - Available benchmarks and their configurations

docs.title: End-to-End Tutorial
docs.text: This tutorial provides a comprehensive walkthrough of using Metriq-Gym, from dispatching benchmarks to uploading results to the Metriq platform.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Before starting, ensure you have:

  • Metriq-Gym installed (pip install metriq-gym)
  • A .env file with provider credentials (see Provider Configuration)

docs.title: Setup
docs.text:
First, load environment variables in your Python session:

from types import SimpleNamespace
from dotenv import load_dotenv
from metriq_gym.run import dispatch_job, poll_job, view_job, upload_job
from metriq_gym.job_manager import JobManager

# Load environment variables from .env file
load_dotenv()

docs.title: Job Handling
docs.text: Metriq-Gym provides a simple API to dispatch jobs to quantum devices and poll/view their status.

docs.title: Dispatching a Job
docs.text:
Use the Python interface to dispatch a job to a quantum device or local simulator:

job_manager = JobManager()
benchmark_path = "metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json"
provider_name = "local"
device_name = "aer_simulator"

dispatch_config = SimpleNamespace(
    config=benchmark_path,
    provider=provider_name,
    device=device_name,
)

dispatch_job(dispatch_config, job_manager)

Output: 

Starting dispatch on local:aer_simulator...
Dispatching WIT...
Job dispatched with metriq-gym Job ID: 7cb5b2df-e62d-423f-ac22-4bf6739d2ea4

Dispatching creates a local .jsonl file that tracks all job metadata.

docs.title: Viewing Job Details
docs.text:
Check job metadata before polling:

jobs = job_manager.get_jobs()
job_id_to_poll = jobs[-1].id

job_config = SimpleNamespace(job_id=job_id_to_poll)
view_job(job_config, job_manager)

This displays a table with job details including provider, device, parameters, and dispatch time.

docs.title: Polling for Results
docs.text:
Poll the job to retrieve results:

poll_job(job_config, job_manager)

Output: 

{
    'app_version': '0.3.1',
    'device': 'aer_simulator',
    'job_type': 'WIT',
    'provider': 'local',
    'results': {'expectation_value': 0.9970703125},
    'suite_id': None,
    'timestamp': '2025-01-15T09:54:47.904520'
}

For the WIT benchmark, the ideal expectation value is 1.0. The simulated result of ~0.997 is very close, indicating correct circuit execution.

docs.title: Uploading Results
docs.text: After polling your job and verifying the results, you can upload them to the Metriq platform via GitHub.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
Set up a GitHub token with repository permissions:

export GITHUB_TOKEN="your-token-here"

Creating a GitHub Token

Create a Personal Access Token at github.com/settings/tokens. For fine-grained tokens, grant Contents (Read and write) and Pull requests (Read and write) permissions.

docs.title: Upload via Python
docs.text:
from types import SimpleNamespace
from metriq_gym.run import upload_job

upload_config = SimpleNamespace(
    job_id=job_id_to_poll,
    repo="unitaryfoundation/metriq-data",  # default repository
    dir=None,  # uses default: metriq-gym/v<version>/<provider>/<device>
)

upload_job(upload_config, job_manager)

docs.title: Upload via CLI
docs.text:
mgym job upload <METRIQ_GYM_JOB_ID>

This creates a pull request to unitaryfoundation/metriq-data containing your benchmark results. Once merged, results appear on metriq.info.

docs.title: Upload Configuration
docs.text:
You can customize the upload destination:

Option Environment Variable Default Target repository MGYM_UPLOAD_REPO unitaryfoundation/metriq-data Base branch MGYM_UPLOAD_BASE_BRANCH main Upload directory MGYM_UPLOAD_DIR metriq-gym/v<major.minor>/<provider>/<device>

docs.title: CLI Equivalents
docs.text:
All operations above can also be performed via the CLI:

# Dispatch
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider local --device aer_simulator

# View
mgym job view <JOB_ID>

# Poll
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

# Upload
mgym job upload <JOB_ID>

Use mgym job poll or mgym job view without arguments to interactively select a job.

docs.title: Running on Real Hardware
docs.text:
To run benchmarks on IBM Quantum hardware:

dispatch_config = SimpleNamespace(
    config="metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json",
    provider="ibm",
    device="ibm_fez",
)

dispatch_job(dispatch_config, job_manager)

Note

Hardware jobs may be queued. Poll periodically to check status and retrieve results when complete.

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• CLI Reference - Detailed command documentation
  • Provider Configuration - Setup guides for all providers
  • Benchmarks - Available benchmarks
  • Metriq Platform - How results appear on metriq.info

docs.title: Azure Quantum
docs.text: Run benchmarks on quantum computers through Microsoft Azure Quantum.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• An Azure account
  • An Azure Quantum workspace
  • Azure Quantum connection string

docs.title: 1. Create an Azure Quantum Workspace
docs.text:
1. Log in to the Azure Portal
  2. Create a new Azure Quantum workspace
  3. Add providers (IonQ, Quantinuum, Rigetti, etc.) to your workspace

docs.title: 2. Get Connection String
docs.text:
1. Navigate to your Azure Quantum workspace
  2. Go to Overview > Connection string
  3. Copy the connection string

docs.title: 3. Configure Environment
docs.text:
Add to your .env file:

AZURE_QUANTUM_CONNECTION_STRING="<your-connection-string>"

The connection string format is: 

SubscriptionId=xxx;ResourceGroupName=xxx;WorkspaceName=xxx;Location=xxx

docs.title: Available Devices
docs.text: Azure Quantum provides access to multiple hardware providers:

docs.title: IonQ
docs.text: Device Description ionq.simulator IonQ simulator ionq.qpu.aria-1 IonQ Aria (25 qubits)

docs.title: Quantinuum
docs.text: Device Description quantinuum.sim.h1-1sc H1-1 syntax checker quantinuum.sim.h1-1e H1-1 emulator quantinuum.qpu.h1-1 H1-1 hardware quantinuum.qpu.h2-1 H2-1 hardware

docs.title: Rigetti
docs.text:
Device Description rigetti.sim.qvm QVM simulator rigetti.qpu.ankaa-9q-3 Ankaa QPU

Note

Available providers depend on your workspace configuration. Enable providers in the Azure Portal.

docs.title: Dispatch to Azure Quantum Hardware
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider azure --device ionq.qpu.aria-1

docs.title: Dispatch to Azure Quantum Simulator
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider azure --device ionq.simulator

docs.title: Poll Results
docs.text: mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Pricing
docs.text:
Azure Quantum uses provider-specific pricing: - IonQ: Per-shot pricing - Quantinuum: HQC-based pricing - Rigetti: Per-shot pricing

Check Azure Quantum Pricing and individual provider pricing for details.

docs.title: Azure Credits
docs.text:
Azure Quantum offers: - Free credits for new users - Academic programs - Research grants

Check eligibility in the Azure Portal.

docs.title: Connection Errors
docs.text:
Verify your connection string:

from azure.quantum import Workspace

workspace = Workspace(
    subscription_id="...",
    resource_group="...",
    name="...",
    location="..."
)
print(workspace.get_targets())

docs.title: Provider Not Available
docs.text: Ensure the provider is: 1. Enabled in your workspace 2. Available in your region 3. Accessible with your subscription tier

docs.title: Job Failures
docs.text: Check job status in the Azure Portal under your workspace's Job management section for detailed error messages.

docs.title: AWS Braket
docs.text: Run benchmarks on quantum computers through Amazon Braket.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• An AWS account
  • AWS credentials with Braket permissions
  • (Optional) An S3 bucket for job results

docs.title: 1. Get AWS Credentials
docs.text:
1. Log in to the AWS Console
  2. Navigate to IAM > Users > Your User > Security credentials
  3. Create an access key

docs.title: 2. Configure Environment
docs.text:
Add to your .env file:

AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID="<your-access-key>"
AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY="<your-secret-key>"

Optionally, set your default region:

AWS_DEFAULT_REGION="us-east-1"

docs.title: Available Devices
docs.text: AWS Braket provides access to multiple hardware providers:

docs.title: IonQ (via Braket)
docs.text: Device Qubits arn:aws:braket:us-east-1::device/qpu/ionq/Aria-1 25 arn:aws:braket:us-east-1::device/qpu/ionq/Forte-1 36

docs.title: Rigetti
docs.text: Device Qubits arn:aws:braket:us-west-1::device/qpu/rigetti/Ankaa-3 84

docs.title: IQM
docs.text: Device Qubits arn:aws:braket:eu-north-1::device/qpu/iqm/Garnet 20

docs.title: Simulators
docs.text:
Device Description arn:aws:braket:::device/quantum-simulator/amazon/sv1 State vector simulator arn:aws:braket:::device/quantum-simulator/amazon/dm1 Density matrix simulator arn:aws:braket:::device/quantum-simulator/amazon/tn1 Tensor network simulator

Note

Device ARNs and availability change. Check the Braket Console for current devices.

docs.title: Dispatch to Braket Hardware
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider braket \
    --device "arn:aws:braket:us-east-1::device/qpu/ionq/Aria-1"

docs.title: Dispatch to Braket Simulator
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider braket \
    --device "arn:aws:braket:::device/quantum-simulator/amazon/sv1"

docs.title: Poll Results
docs.text: mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Pricing
docs.text:
AWS Braket charges: - Per-task fees (fixed cost per job) - Per-shot fees (varies by device) - Simulator fees (per minute of compute time)

Use resource estimation to plan:

mgym job estimate config.json --provider braket

See AWS Braket Pricing for details.

docs.title: Authentication Errors
docs.text:
Verify credentials:

import boto3
client = boto3.client('braket')
print(client.search_devices(filters=[]))

docs.title: Region Issues
docs.text: Some devices are only available in specific regions. Ensure your AWS_DEFAULT_REGION matches the device location.

docs.title: Insufficient Permissions
docs.text: Your IAM user/role needs the AmazonBraketFullAccess policy or equivalent permissions.

docs.title: IBM Quantum
docs.text: Run benchmarks on IBM Quantum hardware through the IBM Quantum Platform.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• An IBM Quantum account
  • An IBM Cloud API key

docs.title: 1. Get Your API Key
docs.text:
1. Log in to IBM Cloud
  2. Navigate to Manage > Access (IAM) > API keys
  3. Create a new API key or use an existing one

docs.title: 2. Configure Environment
docs.text:
Add to your .env file:

# Required
QISKIT_IBM_TOKEN="<your-ibm-cloud-api-key>"

# Optional
QISKIT_IBM_CHANNEL="ibm_quantum_platform"  # or "ibm_quantum"
QISKIT_IBM_INSTANCE="<instance-crn>"       # for specific instance access

docs.title: Available Devices
docs.text:
Device availability depends on your IBM Quantum plan and changes frequently. To see your available devices:

Via IBM Quantum Platform: Visit quantum.ibm.com and check your dashboard.

Via Python: 

from qiskit_ibm_runtime import QiskitRuntimeService

service = QiskitRuntimeService(channel="ibm_quantum_platform")
for backend in service.backends():
    print(f"{backend.name}: {backend.num_qubits} qubits")

Via qBraid: 

from metriq_gym.run import load_provider

provider = load_provider("ibm")
for device in provider.get_devices():
    print(f"{device.id}: {device.status}")

docs.title: Dispatch to IBM Hardware
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/bseq.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_sherbrooke

docs.title: Example Output
docs.text:
Starting dispatch on ibm:ibm_sherbrooke...
Dispatching BSEQ benchmark from bseq.example.json on ibm_sherbrooke...
Job dispatched with ID: 93a06a18-41d8-475a-a030-339fbf3accb9

docs.title: Poll Results
docs.text:
mgym job poll 93a06a18-41d8-475a-a030-339fbf3accb9

If the job is queued: 

Job is queued at position 5. Please try again later.

When complete: 

BSEQResult(largest_connected_size=100, fraction_connected=0.7874)

docs.title: Noise Model Simulation
docs.text:
Run benchmarks locally with IBM device noise models:

mgym job dispatch config.json --provider local --device ibm_sherbrooke

This uses Qiskit Aer with the noise model from the specified IBM device.

docs.title: Resource Estimation
docs.text:
Estimate job resources before dispatch:

mgym job estimate metriq_gym/schemas/examples/bseq.example.json \
    --provider ibm --device ibm_fez

docs.title: Authentication Errors
docs.text:
Ensure your API key is valid and has appropriate permissions:

from qiskit_ibm_runtime import QiskitRuntimeService
service = QiskitRuntimeService(channel="ibm_quantum_platform")
print(service.backends())

docs.title: Device Unavailable
docs.text: Check device status on the IBM Quantum Platform. Devices may be: - Under maintenance - Reserved for specific access levels - Temporarily offline

docs.title: Queue Times
docs.text: IBM Quantum jobs may experience long queue times during peak usage. Consider: - Using simulators for development - Scheduling jobs during off-peak hours - Using fair-share queuing through instance selection

docs.title: IonQ
docs.text: Run benchmarks on IonQ trapped-ion quantum computers.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• An IonQ account
  • An IonQ API key

docs.title: 1. Get Your API Key
docs.text:
1. Log in to IonQ Cloud
  2. Navigate to Settings > API Keys
  3. Create a new API key

docs.title: 2. Configure Environment
docs.text:
Add to your .env file:

IONQ_API_KEY="<your-ionq-api-key>"

docs.title: Available Devices
docs.text:
Device Description ionq_simulator IonQ cloud simulator ionq_harmony 11-qubit trapped-ion system ionq_aria 25-qubit trapped-ion system ionq_forte 36-qubit trapped-ion system

Note

Device availability and qubit counts may change. Check IonQ's documentation for current specifications.

docs.title: Dispatch to IonQ Hardware
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider ionq --device ionq_aria

docs.title: Dispatch to IonQ Simulator
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider ionq --device ionq_simulator

docs.title: Poll Results
docs.text: mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Native Gate Set
docs.text: IonQ uses a native gate set of single-qubit rotations and the MS (Molmer-Sorensen) two-qubit gate. Circuits are automatically transpiled.

docs.title: Debiasing
docs.text: IonQ supports debiasing options for error mitigation. Configure via provider settings if available.

docs.title: Pricing
docs.text:
IonQ charges per shot and circuit complexity. Use resource estimation to plan costs:

mgym job estimate config.json --provider ionq

docs.title: Authentication Errors
docs.text:
Verify your API key:

import os
os.environ["IONQ_API_KEY"] = "your-key"

from qbraid.runtime import load_provider
provider = load_provider("ionq")
print(provider.get_devices())

docs.title: Device Unavailable
docs.text: Check device status on the IonQ Cloud dashboard. Devices may be under maintenance.

docs.title: Local Simulators
docs.text: Run benchmarks locally using Qiskit Aer simulators. This is useful for development, testing, and running benchmarks without cloud access.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text: No additional setup required - Qiskit Aer is included with Metriq-Gym.

docs.title: Basic Simulators
docs.text: Device Description aer_simulator Ideal state vector simulation aer_simulator_statevector State vector simulator (explicit) aer_simulator_density_matrix Density matrix simulator

docs.title: IBM Noise Model Simulators
docs.text:
Use any IBM device name to run with its noise model:

Device Description ibm_sherbrooke 127-qubit Eagle noise model ibm_brisbane 127-qubit Eagle noise model ibm_fez 156-qubit Heron noise model ibm_<device> Any IBM device noise model

Note

Noise model simulators require valid IBM credentials to fetch the noise model, but execution is local.

docs.title: Ideal Simulation
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider local --device aer_simulator

docs.title: Noisy Simulation
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider local --device ibm_sherbrooke

docs.title: Poll Results
docs.text:
mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

Local jobs complete immediately, so polling returns results instantly.

docs.title: Cache Directory
docs.text:
Control where simulator results are cached:

# In .env
MGYM_LOCAL_SIMULATOR_CACHE_DIR="/path/to/cache"

Default: Platform-specific cache directory (e.g., ~/Library/Caches/metriq-gym on macOS)

docs.title: Development and Testing
docs.text:
Test benchmark configurations before running on hardware:

# Quick validation
mgym job dispatch new_config.json -p local -d aer_simulator
mgym job poll latest

docs.title: Benchmarking Simulators
docs.text:
Compare ideal vs. noisy simulation:

# Ideal
mgym job dispatch wit.example.json -p local -d aer_simulator

# With noise
mgym job dispatch wit.example.json -p local -d ibm_sherbrooke

docs.title: Large-Scale Simulations
docs.text:
For benchmarks requiring many qubits:

# Use density matrix for mixed states
mgym job dispatch config.json -p local -d aer_simulator_density_matrix

docs.title: Memory Usage
docs.text:
State vector simulation requires 2^n * 16 bytes of memory for n qubits:

Qubits Memory 20 ~16 MB 25 ~512 MB 30 ~16 GB 35 ~512 GB

docs.title: GPU Acceleration
docs.text: Aer supports GPU acceleration via CUDA. If available, simulations automatically use the GPU.

docs.title: Parallelization
docs.text: For benchmarks with multiple circuits, Aer parallelizes across available CPU cores.

docs.title: Noise Model Details
docs.text:
When using ibm_<device> noise models:

  1. Metriq-Gym fetches the current noise model from IBM Quantum
  2. The model includes:
  3. Single-qubit gate errors
  4. Two-qubit gate errors
  5. Readout errors
  6. T1/T2 decoherence
  7. Circuits are transpiled to the device's basis gates
  8. Simulation runs locally with the noise model applied

docs.title: Noise Model Caching
docs.text:
Noise models are cached to reduce API calls. Clear the cache by deleting:

rm -rf $MGYM_LOCAL_SIMULATOR_CACHE_DIR

docs.title: Out of Memory
docs.text:
Reduce qubit count or use a more efficient simulation method:

# For specific amplitude calculations
mgym job dispatch config.json -p local -d aer_simulator_statevector

docs.title: Slow Simulation
docs.text: For deep circuits: - Reduce shot count for testing - Use ideal simulation without noise models - Consider cloud hardware for production runs

docs.title: OriginQ (Wukong)
docs.text: Run benchmarks on OriginQ Wukong superconducting quantum computers.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• An OriginQ QCloud account
  • OriginQ API token
  • (macOS only) libidn2 library

docs.title: 1. Get Your API Token
docs.text:
1. Log in to the OriginQ Workbench
  2. Navigate to your account settings
  3. Copy your API token

docs.title: 2. Configure Environment
docs.text:
Add to your .env file:

ORIGIN_API_KEY="<your-origin-api-token>"

docs.title: 3. macOS Setup
docs.text:
macOS users must install libidn2 before using the OriginQ provider:

brew reinstall libidn2

Install this library before running uv sync or installing Metriq-Gym to avoid missing symbol errors during the pyqpanda3 build.

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text: Device ID Alias Description WK_C102_400 origin_wukong 102-qubit Wukong hardware 72 - 72-qubit hardware backend

docs.title: Simulators
docs.text: Device ID Max Qubits Description full_amplitude 35 Full state vector simulation partial_amplitude 64 Partial amplitude simulation single_amplitude 100 Single amplitude simulation

docs.title: Dispatch to Wukong Hardware
docs.text:
# Using alias
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider origin --device origin_wukong

# Using numeric ID
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider origin --device 72

docs.title: Dispatch to OriginQ Simulator
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider origin --device full_amplitude

docs.title: Poll Results
docs.text: mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Verify Available Devices
docs.text:
List devices accessible with your account:

uv run python -c "from metriq_gym.run import load_provider; provider = load_provider('origin'); print([device.id for device in provider.get_devices()])"

Or in Python:

from metriq_gym.run import load_provider

provider = load_provider('origin')
devices = provider.get_devices()
for device in devices:
    print(device.id)

docs.title: "resource is null" Error
docs.text:
This error indicates: - The device name is incorrect - Your account lacks permission for the requested device

Verify available devices with the listing command above.

docs.title: Missing libidn2 (macOS)
docs.text:
If you see symbol errors related to pyqpanda3:

# Install the library
brew reinstall libidn2

# Reinstall metriq-gym
pip install --force-reinstall metriq-gym

docs.title: Authentication Errors
docs.text:
Verify your API token is correctly set:

import os
print(os.environ.get("ORIGIN_API_KEY"))

docs.title: Connection Issues
docs.text: OriginQ services are based in China. Connection latency or timeouts may occur from other regions. Consider: - Retrying failed requests - Using longer timeout values - Running during off-peak hours

docs.title: Device Topology
docs.text:
Wukong devices use a 2D grid topology. For topology-dependent benchmarks (BSEQ, Mirror Circuits), the provider automatically retrieves connectivity information.

from metriq_gym.run import load_provider

provider = load_provider('origin')
device = provider.get_device('origin_wukong')
# Topology available via device.metadata

docs.title: Provider Configuration
docs.text: Metriq-Gym supports multiple quantum hardware providers through a unified interface built on qBraid Runtime.

docs.title: Supported Providers
docs.text: Provider Provider ID Description IBM Quantum ibm IBM's quantum computers and simulators IonQ ionq IonQ trapped-ion quantum computers AWS Braket braket Amazon Braket quantum computing service Azure Quantum azure Microsoft Azure Quantum Quantinuum quantinuum Quantinuum H-series trapped-ion systems OriginQ origin OriginQ Wukong superconducting systems Local Simulators local Qiskit Aer local simulation

docs.title: Provider Architecture
docs.text: Metriq-Gym uses two types of provider integrations:

docs.title: qBraid-Managed Providers
docs.text:
IBM, IonQ, Braket, and Azure use qBraid Runtime's native provider support:

from qbraid.runtime import load_provider
provider = load_provider("ibm")

docs.title: Custom Providers
docs.text:
Local, Quantinuum (NEXUS), and OriginQ use custom provider implementations registered via entry points:

# Registered in pyproject.toml
[project.entry-points."qbraid.providers"]
local = "metriq_gym.local.provider:LocalProvider"
quantinuum = "metriq_gym.quantinuum.provider:QuantinuumProvider"
origin = "metriq_gym.origin.provider:OriginProvider"

docs.title: Credential Configuration
docs.text:
Create a .env file in your project root with provider credentials:

# Copy the template
cp .env.example .env

# Edit with your credentials
nano .env

docs.title: Environment Variables Reference
docs.text: Variable Provider Description QISKIT_IBM_TOKEN IBM IBM Cloud API key QISKIT_IBM_CHANNEL IBM Channel type (optional) QISKIT_IBM_INSTANCE IBM Instance CRN (optional) IONQ_API_KEY IonQ IonQ API key AWS_ACCESS_KEY_ID Braket AWS access key AWS_SECRET_ACCESS_KEY Braket AWS secret key AZURE_QUANTUM_CONNECTION_STRING Azure Azure connection string QUANTINUUM_NEXUS_USERNAME Quantinuum NEXUS username QUANTINUUM_NEXUS_PASSWORD Quantinuum NEXUS password ORIGIN_API_KEY OriginQ OriginQ API token

docs.title: Device Selection
docs.text:
List available devices for a provider:

from metriq_gym.run import load_provider

provider = load_provider("ibm")
devices = provider.get_devices()
for device in devices:
    print(f"{device.id}: {device.status}")

Via CLI, use provider-specific documentation to find device names.

docs.title: Dispatch to Hardware
docs.text: mgym job dispatch config.json --provider ibm --device ibm_fez

docs.title: Dispatch to Simulator with Noise Model
docs.text:
# Use local provider with IBM noise model
mgym job dispatch config.json --provider local --device ibm_sherbrooke

docs.title: Check Job Status
docs.text: mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
• IBM Quantum - IBM Quantum Platform setup
  • IonQ - IonQ Cloud setup
  • AWS Braket - Amazon Braket setup
  • Azure Quantum - Azure Quantum setup
  • Quantinuum - Quantinuum NEXUS setup
  • OriginQ - OriginQ Wukong setup
  • Local Simulators - Running benchmarks locally

docs.title: Quantinuum
docs.text: Run benchmarks on Quantinuum H-series trapped-ion quantum computers through the NEXUS platform.

docs.title: Prerequisites
docs.text:
• A Quantinuum NEXUS account
  • NEXUS credentials (username and password)

docs.title: 1. Get NEXUS Credentials
docs.text:
1. Register at Quantinuum NEXUS
  2. Note your username and password

docs.title: 2. Configure Environment
docs.text:
Add to your .env file:

QUANTINUUM_NEXUS_USERNAME="<your-username>"
QUANTINUUM_NEXUS_PASSWORD="<your-password>"
QUANTINUUM_NEXUS_PROJECT_NAME="metriq-gym"

# Optional: optimization level for compilation (default: 1)
QUANTINUUM_NEXUS_OPT_LEVEL="1"

docs.title: 3. Initial Login
docs.text:
The first time you use Quantinuum, you must complete a manual login workflow:

qnx login

Follow the prompts to authenticate and link your account.

docs.title: Hardware
docs.text: Device Qubits Description H1-1 20 H1 generation system H2-1 56 H2 generation system

docs.title: Emulators
docs.text: Device Description H1-1E H1-1 emulator with realistic noise H2-1E H2-1 emulator with realistic noise

docs.title: Syntax Checkers
docs.text:
Device Description H1-1SC H1-1 syntax validation (no execution) H2-1SC H2-1 syntax validation (no execution)

Tip

Use syntax checkers to validate circuits before running on hardware. They're free and instant.

docs.title: Dispatch to Quantinuum Hardware
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider quantinuum --device H1-1

docs.title: Dispatch to Emulator
docs.text:
mgym job dispatch metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider quantinuum --device H1-1E

docs.title: Poll Results
docs.text: mgym job poll <JOB_ID>

docs.title: H-series Quantum Credits (HQCs)
docs.text:
Quantinuum uses HQCs for billing. The formula is:

HQC = 5 + C * (N1 + 10*N2 + 5*Nm) / 5000

Where: - C = number of shots - N1 = single-qubit gate count - N2 = two-qubit gate count - Nm = measurement count

docs.title: Estimate HQCs Before Running
docs.text:
mgym job estimate metriq_gym/schemas/examples/wit.example.json \
    --provider quantinuum

Example output: 

Quantinuum HQC estimate: 52.4

docs.title: NEXUS Projects
docs.text:
Jobs are organized into NEXUS projects. Set the project name:

QUANTINUUM_NEXUS_PROJECT_NAME="my-project"

docs.title: Compilation Optimization
docs.text:
Control TKET compilation optimization:

# Levels: 0 (none), 1 (default), 2 (aggressive)
QUANTINUUM_NEXUS_OPT_LEVEL="2"

Higher levels may reduce gate counts but increase compilation time.

docs.title: Login Required
docs.text:
If you see authentication errors, re-run:

qnx login

docs.title: HQC Limits
docs.text: Check your HQC balance in the NEXUS portal. Jobs exceeding your balance will fail.

docs.title: Compilation Errors
docs.text: Some circuits may not compile efficiently for trapped-ion hardware. Try: - Reducing circuit depth - Using optimization level 2 - Checking for unsupported operations

docs.title: GitHub Integration
docs.text: Metriq-Gym uploads benchmark results to GitHub via pull requests, enabling community contribution to the benchmark database.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The upload workflow: 1. Creates a fork of the target repository (if needed) 2. Creates a new branch with your results 3. Opens a pull request for review 4. Once merged, results appear on metriq.info

docs.title: 1. Create a GitHub Token
docs.text:
Create a Personal Access Token at github.com/settings/tokens.

For Classic Tokens: - Select the repo scope

For Fine-Grained Tokens: - Resource owner: Your account - Repository access: All repositories (to cover future forks) - Permissions: - Contents: Read and write - Pull requests: Read and write

docs.title: 2. Configure Environment
docs.text:
Add to your .env file:

GITHUB_TOKEN="your-token-here"

# Optional: customize upload destination
MGYM_UPLOAD_REPO="unitaryfoundation/metriq-data"
MGYM_UPLOAD_BASE_BRANCH="main"
MGYM_UPLOAD_DIR=""

docs.title: Single Job
docs.text: mgym job upload <JOB_ID>

docs.title: Full Suite
docs.text: mgym suite upload <SUITE_ID>

docs.title: Upload Options
docs.text: Option Environment Variable Default Description --repo MGYM_UPLOAD_REPO unitaryfoundation/metriq-data Target repository --dir MGYM_UPLOAD_DIR metriq-gym/v<version>/<provider>/<device> Directory path

docs.title: Examples
docs.text:
# Default upload
mgym job upload abc123

# Custom repository
mgym job upload abc123 --repo myorg/my-data

# Custom directory
mgym job upload abc123 --dir results/2025/january

docs.title: 1. Fork Creation
docs.text: If you don't have a fork of the target repository, Metriq-Gym automatically creates one.

docs.title: 2. Branch Creation
docs.text: A branch named mgym/upload-<job_id> is created with your results.

docs.title: 3. File Structure
docs.text:
Results are stored as JSON files:

metriq-gym/
└── v0.3/
    └── ibm/
        └── ibm_sherbrooke/
            └── 2025-01-15T12:00:00_BSEQ_abc123.json

docs.title: 4. Pull Request
docs.text: A PR is opened with: - Title: mgym upload: <benchmark> on <provider>/<device> - Labels: data, source:metriq-gym

docs.title: Result File Format
docs.text:
[
  {
    "app_version": "0.3.1",
    "timestamp": "2025-01-15T12:00:00.000000",
    "platform": {
      "provider": "ibm",
      "device": "ibm_sherbrooke"
    },
    "job_type": "BSEQ",
    "results": {
      "values": {
        "largest_connected_size": 100,
        "fraction_connected": 0.7874
      },
      "uncertainties": {
        "fraction_connected": 0.01
      }
    },
    "params": {
      "benchmark_name": "BSEQ",
      "shots": 1000
    }
  }
]

docs.title: First-Time Contributors
docs.text:
1. Your fork is created automatically
  2. Review the PR before requesting merge
  3. Maintainers review and merge contributions

docs.title: Repeat Contributors
docs.text: Subsequent uploads use your existing fork and create new branches.

docs.title: "GitHub token not provided"
docs.text:
Ensure GITHUB_TOKEN is set:

export GITHUB_TOKEN="your-token"
# or add to .env file

docs.title: Fork Creation Failed
docs.text: If automatic forking fails: 1. Manually fork unitaryfoundation/metriq-data 2. Retry the upload command

docs.title: Permission Denied
docs.text: Verify your token has the required permissions: - repo scope for classic tokens - Contents + Pull requests for fine-grained tokens

docs.title: PR Creation Failed
docs.text: If PR creation fails, the command returns a compare URL. Open it in your browser to manually create the PR.

docs.title: Best Practices
docs.text:
1. Review before upload: Verify results with mgym job poll --json first
  2. Don't upload test runs: Only upload meaningful benchmark results
  3. Include metadata: Results automatically include version, timestamp, and configuration
  4. One PR per upload: Each upload creates a separate PR for easy review

docs.title: External Contributors
docs.text:
If you're contributing from outside the Unitary Foundation:

  1. Fork unitaryfoundation/metriq-data manually (recommended)
  2. Set MGYM_UPLOAD_REPO to your fork
  3. Create PRs from your fork to the upstream repository

docs.title: Programmatic Upload
docs.text:
Use the Python API for custom upload workflows:

from types import SimpleNamespace
from metriq_gym.run import upload_job
from metriq_gym.job_manager import JobManager

job_manager = JobManager()

upload_config = SimpleNamespace(
    job_id="your-job-id",
    repo="unitaryfoundation/metriq-data",
    dir=None,  # use default
)

upload_job(upload_config, job_manager)

docs.title: Metriq Platform
docs.text: Metriq-Gym is part of the Metriq ecosystem for tracking quantum computing progress. This page explains how your uploaded results appear on the platform.

docs.title: The Metriq Ecosystem
docs.text:
┌─────────────┐     ┌─────────────┐     ┌─────────────┐
│ metriq-gym  │ ──▶ │ metriq-data │ ──▶ │ metriq.info │
│  (collect)  │     │   (store)   │     │  (display)  │
└─────────────┘     └─────────────┘     └─────────────┘
  1. Metriq-Gym: Run benchmarks and collect results
  2. metriq-data: GitHub repository storing all benchmark data
  3. metriq.info: Web platform displaying results and trends

docs.title: Metriq.info
docs.text:
Visit metriq.info to explore:

  • Historical benchmark results across devices
  • Performance trends over time
  • Device comparisons
  • Community contributions

Note

The Metriq platform is currently available at beta.metriq.info. The URL will transition to metriq.info at launch.

docs.title: Result Discovery
docs.text: The metriq-data repository is periodically scanned for new results. Merged PRs are automatically processed.

docs.title: Result Display
docs.text: Results are displayed with: - Device and provider information - Benchmark type and parameters - Metric values with uncertainties - Timestamp and software version

docs.title: Historical Tracking
docs.text: The platform tracks results over time, allowing you to see: - How device performance changes - Calibration effects - Long-term trends

docs.title: Data Format
docs.text:
Results in metriq-data follow a standardized format:

{
  "app_version": "0.3.1",
  "timestamp": "2025-01-15T12:00:00.000000",
  "platform": {
    "provider": "ibm",
    "device": "ibm_sherbrooke"
  },
  "job_type": "Quantum Volume",
  "results": {
    "values": {
      "quantum_volume": 32,
      "heavy_output_probability": 0.68
    },
    "uncertainties": {
      "heavy_output_probability": 0.02
    }
  },
  "params": {
    "benchmark_name": "Quantum Volume",
    "num_qubits": 5,
    "shots": 1000,
    "trials": 100
  }
}

docs.title: Key Fields
docs.text: Field Description app_version Metriq-Gym version used timestamp When the benchmark was run platform.provider Hardware provider platform.device Specific device job_type Benchmark type results.values Metric values results.uncertainties Statistical uncertainties params Benchmark configuration

docs.title: Contributing Quality Data
docs.text: To ensure your results are valuable:

docs.title: Do
docs.text:
• Run benchmarks with sufficient shots (1000+)
  • Use recommended trial counts for statistical significance
  • Include all relevant parameters
  • Verify results before uploading

docs.title: Don't
docs.text:
• Upload test runs or debugging data
  • Artificially cherry-pick results
  • Modify result files manually
  • Upload duplicate results

docs.title: metriq-data Repository
docs.text:
The unitaryfoundation/metriq-data repository:

  • Is open source and community-driven
  • Accepts contributions via pull requests
  • Uses automated validation
  • Is backed up regularly

docs.title: Directory Structure
docs.text:
metriq-data/
├── metriq-gym/
│   ├── v0.3/
│   │   ├── ibm/
│   │   │   ├── ibm_sherbrooke/
│   │   │   │   └── 2025-01-15T12:00:00_BSEQ_abc123.json
│   │   │   └── ibm_fez/
│   │   │       └── ...
│   │   ├── ionq/
│   │   └── local/
│   └── v0.4/
└── ...

docs.title: Via GitHub
docs.text:
Browse or clone the repository:

git clone https://github.com/unitaryfoundation/metriq-data.git

docs.title: Via Metriq API
docs.text:
The Metriq platform provides an API for programmatic access:

# Get your API key at https://metriq.info/Token
export METRIQ_CLIENT_API_KEY="your-key"

docs.title: Community and Support
docs.text:
• Report issues: metriq-gym issues
  • Data questions: metriq-data discussions
  • Platform feedback: Contact the Unitary Foundation team

docs.title: Related Links
docs.text:
• Metriq Platform
  • metriq-data Repository
  • Unitary Foundation
